Fungal infection.description: Superficial fungal infection of skin or nails caused by dermatophytes or yeasts.
precautions: Use antifungal creams or powders as prescribed
Wear clean and breathable cotton clothing
workout: Light activity; avoid heavy sweating until cleared

Allergy.description: Immune reaction to allergens such as pollen, dust or certain foods.
precautions: Use clean bedding and dust-free items
Consult a doctor if swelling occurs
workout: Light breathing exercises (avoid outdoors during high pollen times)

GERD.description: Gastroesophageal reflux disease — chronic acid reflux causing heartburn and regurgitation.
precautions: Do not lie down immediately after meals
Eat smaller and more frequent meals
workout: Light walking after meals; avoid high-impact exercise after eating

Chronic cholestasis.description: Impaired bile flow causing jaundice and itching; requires specialist care.
precautions: Take bile acid supplements as prescribed
Consult a hepatologist for persistent symptoms
workout: Gentle walking and light activity as tolerated

Drug Reaction.description: Adverse response to a medication; presentation ranges from rash to systemic symptoms.
precautions: Inform your doctor as soon as possible
Carry medical ID if drug allergies exist
workout: Rest until symptoms resolve

Peptic ulcer disease.description: Ulcer formation in stomach or duodenum often due to H. pylori or NSAID use.
precautions: Eat on time and avoid skipping meals
Take antacids or PPIs as prescribed
diet: Bland soft meals: porridge, bananas, boiled vegetables
workout: Light walking; avoid heavy lifting or straining

AIDS.description: Advanced HIV infection causing immune suppression and opportunistic infections.
precautions: Maintain hygiene to reduce opportunistic infections
medications: ART regimen as prescribed by specialist
workout: Gentle exercise per tolerance; avoid exhaustion during active infections

Diabetes.description: Metabolic disorder characterized by high blood glucose requiring lifestyle and medication control.
precautions: Avoid stress as it spikes sugar levels
Take insulin or medication as prescribed
diet: Low carb meals, whole grains, vegetables
workout: Regular walking, resistance training; monitor glucose around activity

Gastroenteritis.description: Inflammation of stomach and intestines causing diarrhea and vomiting (usually infectious).
precautions: Stay hydrated with ORS or electrolyte drinks
Eat soft, bland foods when recovering
Seek doctor help if vomiting persists
medications: Antibiotics only if bacterial cause suspected
diet: BRAT diet: bananas, rice, applesauce, toast during recovery
workout: Rest until rehydrated and eating normally

Bronchial Asthma.description: Chronic airway inflammation leading to episodic wheeze, cough and breathlessness.
precautions: Avoid dust, smoke, and strong scents
Use air purifier in polluted areas
Stay away from cold air if sensitive
diet: Avoid foods that trigger your asthma; maintain good nutrition
workout: Controlled breathing exercises; warm up before exercise

Hypertension.description: Persistently elevated blood pressure increasing cardiovascular risk.
diet: DASH-style diet: fruits, vegetables, low-salt foods
workout: Regular aerobic activity: brisk walking, cycling

Migraine.description: Recurrent severe headaches often with sensory sensitivity and nausea.
precautions: Avoid bright light and loud noise
Rest in a dark silent room
Avoid trigger foods like chocolate and cheese
diet: Avoid known trigger foods; maintain regular meals
workout: Relaxation and gentle aerobic exercise; avoid strenuous exertion during attacks

Cervical spondylosis.description: Degenerative changes in neck vertebrae causing pain and stiffness.
precautions: Use heating pad or warm compress
diet: Balanced diet for bone health (calcium, vitamin D)
workout: Neck stretches and physiotherapy exercises

Paralysis (brain hemorrhage).description: Neurological deficit due to bleeding in the brain; medical emergency and rehabilitation needed.
precautions: Prevent bedsores and keep skin clean
medications: Dependent on cause — follow neurology advice
workout: Physiotherapy-guided rehabilitation exercises

Jaundice.description: Yellowing of eyes/skin due to elevated bilirubin; has many causes including liver disease.
precautions: Drink plenty of water and coconut water
Take liver-protective diet like fruits and greens
medications: Supportive treatment; antivirals if viral hepatitis
diet: Light, easily digestible meals; avoid heavy/fatty foods
workout: Rest and avoid vigorous exercise during acute illness

Malaria.description: Mosquito-borne protozoal infection causing fever, chills, and systemic symptoms.
diet: Hydrating fluids; easy-to-digest food during fever
workout: Rest until cleared of infection

Chicken pox.description: Varicella viral infection causing fever and itchy vesicular rash; contagious.
workout: Rest; avoid strenuous activity until healed

Dengue.description: Mosquito-borne viral infection causing fever, body aches, and potential bleeding complications.
precautions: Seek hospital care if bleeding occurs
diet: Hydrating fluids and light nutritious meals
workout: Strict rest until platelet recovery

Typhoid.description: Systemic bacterial infection causing high fever, abdominal pain and malaise.
medications: Appropriate antibiotics (e.g., ceftriaxone, azithromycin) as per sensitivity
diet: Light, bland meals; avoid street food
workout: Rest until medically cleared

Hepatitis A.description: Viral liver infection usually transmitted by contaminated food/water; often self-limited.
workout: Rest until liver enzymes normalize

Hepatitis B.description: Viral infection affecting the liver; may be acute or chronic requiring treatment.
workout: Light exercise as tolerated; avoid overexertion in acute phase

Hepatitis C.description: Chronic viral liver infection treatable with modern antivirals.
diet: Balanced diet; avoid high-fat processed foods
workout: Light to moderate exercise as tolerated

Hepatitis D.description: Delta hepatitis, occurs with HBV and can be severe; specialist care required.
medications: Specialist-prescribed antivirals or interferon in certain cases
workout: Rest or gentle activity per doctor advice

Hepatitis E.description: Typically waterborne viral hepatitis, often self-limited but risky in pregnancy.
medications: Supportive care; hospitalize if severe or in pregnancy
workout: Rest during acute illness

Alcoholic hepatitis.description: Liver inflammation from excessive alcohol intake.
diet: Nutrient-rich, avoid alcohol and processed fats
workout: Light exercise once stable; supervised rehab for alcohol use disorder

Tuberculosis.description: Bacterial infection usually of lungs, treatable with prolonged antibiotics.
workout: Gradual return to activity; rest during active disease

Common Cold.description: Acute viral upper respiratory infection causing sneezing, sore throat, runny nose.
precautions: Avoid cold drinks and AC if symptomatic
diet: Warm soups, fluids, vitamin C rich foods
workout: Rest until symptoms improve

Pneumonia.description: Lung infection causing cough, fever, breathlessness; may be bacterial or viral.
medications: Appropriate antibiotics or antivirals as directed
workout: Rest until clinically recovered

Dimorphic hemmorhoids(piles).description: Enlarged swollen veins in anal canal causing pain and bleeding.
medications: Topical creams, stool softeners as advised
workout: Gentle walking; avoid straining

Heart attack.description: Acute coronary event due to blocked coronary artery — medical emergency.
workout: Strict rest during acute phase; cardiac rehab when stable

Varicose veins.description: Enlarged superficial veins often in legs causing heaviness and swelling.
medications: Symptomatic creams; surgical options for severe cases
diet: Maintain healthy weight; avoid salt excess
workout: Walking and calf-strengthening exercises

Hypothyroidism.description: Underactive thyroid producing low thyroid hormone levels.
diet: Iodine containing foods if deficient; balanced nutrition
workout: Regular moderate exercise to boost metabolism

Hyperthyroidism.description: Excess thyroid hormone causing weight loss, palpitations and tremor.
workout: Light exercise; avoid overexertion during uncontrolled phase

Hypoglycemia.description: Low blood sugar causing sweating, dizziness, confusion; needs immediate sugar.
precautions: Carry sugary snacks or glucose gel
medications: Immediate glucose (oral) if conscious; glucagon injection if severe
diet: Regular small meals with complex carbs and protein
workout: Monitor glucose pre/post exercise; keep quick sugar handy

Osteoarthristis.description: Degenerative joint disease causing pain and reduced mobility.
precautions: Use warm compress for pain relief
Use pain relief gels as needed
workout: Low-impact exercises: swimming, cycling, physiotherapy

Arthritis.description: Inflammatory joint disease causing pain, swelling and stiffness.
medications: NSAIDs, DMARDs for certain forms (as prescribed)
diet: Omega-3 rich foods, fruits and vegetables
workout: Regular gentle exercise and physiotherapy

(vertigo) Paroymsal Positional Vertigo.description: Brief episodes of vertigo triggered by head position change due to inner ear crystal displacement.
workout: Balance/vestibular rehabilitation exercises

Acne.description: Clogged hair follicles causing pimples; common in adolescents and adults.
precautions: Wash face twice daily with mild cleanser
medications: Benzoyl peroxide, topical retinoids, antibiotics (as needed)
diet: Balanced diet; reduce high glycemic foods if triggering acne
workout: Regular exercise; shower after sweating

Urinary tract infection.description: Infection of urinary tract causing pain, burning and increased frequency.
precautions: Wipe front to back after toileting
diet: Plenty of fluids; cranberry juice may help
workout: Light activity; avoid strenuous exertion during acute infection

Psoriasis.description: Chronic autoimmune skin disease causing red scaly patches.
medications: Topical corticosteroids, vitamin D analogues, systemic drugs in severe cases
workout: Light exercise; avoid overheating if triggers flare

Impetigo.description: Contagious superficial bacterial skin infection producing honey-colored crusts.
medications: Topical mupirocin; oral antibiotics if extensive
diet: General healthy diet to support immunity
workout: Avoid excessive sweating until healed
